column1: MAT437H1:K-Theory and C* Algebras::36L:The theory of operator algebras was begun by John von Neumann eighty years ago. In one of the most important innovations of this theory
column2: von Neumann and Murray introduced a notion of equivalence of projections in a self-adjoint algebra (*-algebra) of Hilbert space operators that was compatible with addition of orthogonal projections (also in matrix algebras over the algebra)
column3: and so gave rise to an abelian semigroup
column4: now referred to as the Murray-von Neumann semigroup. Later

column8: considered similar constructions. The enveloping group of the semigroup considered in each of these settings is now referred to as the K-group (Grothendieck's terminology)
column9: or as the Grothendieck group. Among the many indications of the depth of this construction was the discovery of Atiyah and Hirzebruch that Bott periodicity could be expressed in a simple way using the K-group. Also
column10: Atiyah and Singer famously showed that K-theory was important in connection with the Fredholm index. Partly because of these developments
column11: K-theory very soon became important again in the theory of operator algebras. (And in turn
column12: operator algebras became increasingly important in other branches of mathematics.) The purpose of this course is to give a general

column18: and to prove that the class of these C*-algebras---what Bratteli called AF algebras---is closed under passing to extensions (a result that uses the Bott periodicity feature of K-theory).
